factoid: The irate colonel said, "I peg of you yourself not to mix in vot is not your business!"
The colonel said, "If you vere in the cavalry..."
The Russian general said, "I am not in the cavalry, Colonel, but I am a Russian general and if you are not aware of the fact..."
The colonel shouted, "Quite avare, your excellency," and touched his horse while turning purple in the face.
The colonel asked, "Vill you be so goot to come to ze front and see dat zis position iss no goot? I don’t vish to destroy my men for your pleasure!"
The Russian general replied, "You forget yourself, Colonel. I am not considering my own pleasure and I won’t allow it to be said!"
The general expanded his chest and rode beside the colonel to the front line in response to the colonel’s outburst.
The general and the colonel reached the front line together.
Several bullets passed over the general and the colonel as they halted in silence.
The cavalry could not act among the bushes and broken ground.
The French were outflanking the Russian left flank.
The general and the colonel looked sternly at one another like two fighting cocks preparing for battle.
The general and the colonel were each vainly trying to detect signs of cowardice in the other.
Both the general and the colonel passed the examination of courage successfully.
The general and the colonel did not want to give occasion for it to be alleged that the general had been the first to leave the range of fire.
The general and the colonel heard the rattle of musketry and a muffled shout behind them in the wood.
The French attacked the men collecting wood in the copse.
It was no longer possible for the hussars to retreat with the infantry.
The hussars were cut off from the line of retreat on the left by the French.
The position was inconvenient but it was necessary to attack in order to cut a way through for themselves.
The squadron in which Rostóv was serving had scarcely time to mount before it was halted facing the enemy.
There was nothing between the squadron and the enemy, and a terrible dividing line of uncertainty and fear lay between them.
All soldiers were conscious of this unseen line.
The soldiers were agitated by the question of whether they would cross the line and how they would cross it.
The colonel rode to the front and angrily gave a reply to questions put to him by the officers.
The colonel gave an order.
Rumor of an attack spread through the squadron.
The command to form up rang out and sabers whizzed as they were drawn from their scabbards.
No one moved.
The troops of the left flank, infantry and hussars alike, felt that the commander did not know what to do.
The commander’s indecision communicated itself to the men.
Rostóv thought, "If only they would be quick!"
Rostóv felt that the time had come to experience the joy of an attack he had often heard about from his fellow hussars.
Denísov’s voice rang out, "Fo’ward, with God, lads! At a twot fo’ward!"
The horses’ croups began to sway in the front line.
Rook pulled at the reins and started of his own accord.
Rostóv saw the front lines of his hussars on the right.
Rostóv saw a dark line ahead that he could not see distinctly but took to be the enemy.
Shots could be heard some way off.
The command "Faster!" was given.
Rostóv felt Rook’s flanks drooping as Rook broke into a gallop.
Rostóv anticipated his horse’s movements and became more elated.
Rostóv noticed a solitary tree ahead of him.
The tree had been in the middle of a terrible line that Rostóv had crossed.
After crossing the line, there was nothing terrible and everything was becoming more happy and animated.
Rostóv thought, "Oh, how I will slash at him!" and gripped the hilt of his saber.
